lines.content: I had a lot of fun coding with OpenCode. I could spawn tons of sessions at once, and have plenty of credits through their free models (with limits) such as Kimi K2.5 and GLM5, which are actually quite good. Sometimes, I hit limits or have more sophisticated tasks. In these cases, I would use GitHub Copilot's API instead. It provides access to SOTA models like Claude Opus 4.6 and Sonnet 4.6.

OpenCode felt very lightweight because it is a TUI and navigable via solely the keyboard (often just keys near the homerow). E.g., switching models, or between build and plan modes takes just a second and I don't need to take my hand off the keyboard. I could also easily reference files as context, and it had great UX.

I also use GitHub Copilot as a reviewer for my pull requests. It has helped me catch bugs and code logic flaws that are hard to spot. In many cases, it is able to detect code quality or logic issues that are hard to spot, e.g. subtle off-by-one errors in loop bounds, incorrect handling of edge cases in conditional logic, or methods that silently swallow exceptions without proper error propagation. In other cases, it is still safe as I still will look at these suggestions and decide whether they are valid, or whether there is extra context and nuance that the reviewer may have missed. I can either reference directly in a new issue to keep track of it, or sometimes spawn a Copilot session to have trivial bugs fixed, which then frees me to work on the next feature instead of tweaking a 95% done one.
* Although I did not provide much context, the LLM was able to accurately follow Jackson's API and implement correctly. I assume this is due to Jackson's API being mature and well-documented.
* To deepen my understanding, I further conversed with the LLM to understand the API's syntax.
* This saved me time and effort to look for the API documentation.
* Reference: Refer to [this file](ai-usage/cursor_data_loading_and_storing_strategy.md) for detailed chat log.
## Identifying Git Commit Hashes for Tags
* I had a large backlog of requirement tags to add after extensive development work, and needed to identify which merge commits corresponded to each tag requirement.

* The AI effectively analyzed git history using multiple parallel bash commands to examine branches, merge commits, and commit relationships. It was able to identify commits that were a match for each tag.
* This was an easy task as many commits were merge commits with commit messages that clearly matched the tags, e.g. "Merge branch-A-CI into master" matches the tags "A-CI".
* I then prompt it to generate ready-to-use git tag commands with proper annotations, saving significant manual effort for writing it.
* This was particularly useful because manually searching through extensive commit history would have been time-consuming and error-prone.
* Reference: Refer to [this file](ai-usage/opencode_git_tag_identification.md) for detailed chat log.
## User Guide Date and Time Section
* Documentation is tedious. I wrote the code and understand the logic, plus, the logic is easily readable through the code. I just needed someone to navigate it and write it up.
* I provided `DateTimeParser.java` and `DateTimeParserTest.java` as context. The AI read the existing user guide, identified what was missing or inaccurate, and added the date/time section.
* The AI accurately captured all the nuances because it was explicit through code and test cases.
* Since I coded this part, I understood the nuances of the output and checked and tweaked the AI response afterwards.
* Reference: Refer to [this file](ai-usage/opencode_user_guide_date_section.md) for detailed chat log.
# I would like to join this list. How can I help the project
For more information, please refer to our [contributor's guide](https://oss-generic.github.io/process/).
> "I don't need to know everything. I just need to know where to find it." - Albert Einstein
Arnold provides a seamless interface to unlock everlasting memory. *Never forget a thing again.*
2. Run the following command within the enclosing folder of the JAR file.
3. Launch the `help` command in the Arnold app interface to learn about what you can do with Arnold.
4. Add your tasks and free your mind! ðŸ§ ðŸŽ‰

The data loading and storing strategy now is not really sound. It uses the input processor and task commands to store. This however omits information such as whether a task is done. Moreover, I would like to use json to serialise so that it can be robust to symbols (instead of using "|" as separators, for example)
Let me explore the codebase to understand the current data loading/storing strategy and overall architecture.
Now let me read the key files to get the exact code.
Let me check if `asCommand()` and `getTasksAsCommands()` are used anywhere beyond the storage flow.
Let me also check the existing tests to understand what needs to stay compatible.
I now have a thorough understanding of the current codebase. Here's a summary of the issues and my proposed plan.
I'll update the plan to use Jackson instead of Gson.
The plan has been updated to use **Jackson** instead of Gson. The key differences:

- **Custom serializer/deserializer**: Jackson's `StdSerializer<Task>` / `StdDeserializer<Task>` registered via a `SimpleModule` on the `ObjectMapper`, rather than Gson's `JsonSerializer`/`JsonDeserializer`
- **JSR-310 module**: Jackson has a dedicated module for Java 8 date/time types, so `LocalDateTime` is handled cleanly out of the box
Everything else (the JSON format, the architectural changes, what gets removed) stays the same. Let me know when you'd like to proceed.
Implement the plan as specified, it is attached for your reference. Do NOT edit the plan file itself.
To-do's from the plan have already been created. Do not create them again. Mark them as in_progress as you work, starting with the first one. Don't stop until you have completed all the to-dos.
Now adding the date getters to `Deadline` and `Event`.
Now creating the custom Jackson serializer and deserializer.
Now modifying `TaskList.java` â€” adding `getTasks()`, `loadTasks()`, and removing `getTasksAsCommands()`.
Now removing `asCommand()` from the Task hierarchy.
Now let me check for linter errors across the modified files and verify everything compiles.
Let me also verify the build compiles and tests pass.
Checkstyle requires Javadoc on public classes/methods, and there's an unused import. Let me fix those.
The file already has Javadoc. Let me just rebuild to confirm all checkstyle issues are resolved.
Build successful â€” all 28 tests pass and checkstyle is clean. Let me also check the `TaskList.java` checkstyle didn't flag the new methods missing Javadoc.
The build passed with checkstyle, so the new methods are fine. All done.
All tasks are complete. Here's a summary of what was done:

2. **`TaskSerializer.java`** (new) -- Custom Jackson `StdSerializer<Task>` that writes each task as a JSON object with `type`, `description`, `isDone`, and type-specific date fields (`by` / `from` + `to`) using ISO-8601 format.

3. **`TaskDeserializer.java`** (new) -- Custom Jackson `StdDeserializer<Task>` that reads the `type` field to construct the correct subclass, restores `isDone` via `mark()`, and parses ISO date strings back to `LocalDateTime`.

4. **`TaskFileStorage.java`** -- Completely rewritten. Uses an `ObjectMapper` with the custom serializer/deserializer instead of replaying commands through `InputProcessor`. The `InputProcessor` dependency is fully removed.
5. **`TaskList.java`** -- Replaced `getTasksAsCommands()` with `getTasks()` (unmodifiable view) and `loadTasks(List<Task>)` (bulk-add without triggering saves).
6. **`Task.java`, `Todo.java`, `Deadline.java`, `Event.java`** -- Removed `asCommand()` from the entire hierarchy. Added `getBy()`, `getFrom()`, `getTo()` getters on the date-bearing subclasses.
The build passes cleanly (all 28 tests green, checkstyle clean). Tasks now persist their full state including `isDone`, and the JSON format is robust against special characters in descriptions.
why can't we just serialise based on fields? isn't there an "annotation" workaround?

You're right â€” we absolutely can use Jackson annotations to avoid the custom serializer/deserializer classes entirely. The reason I went with custom classes is that the `Task` hierarchy has a few quirks (no default constructors, `isDone` set only via `mark()`, polymorphic subclasses), but Jackson annotations handle all of these natively:
- **`@JsonCreator` + `@JsonProperty`** on subclass constructors handles deserialization without default constructors
- **`@JsonProperty("isDone")`** on the field lets Jackson read/write it directly via reflection, bypassing the lack of a setter
The annotation approach would look like this on `Task`:
And on each subclass constructor, e.g. `Deadline`:
public Deadline(@JsonProperty("description") String description, @JsonProperty("by") LocalDateTime by) {

This would **delete both `TaskSerializer.java` and `TaskDeserializer.java`** entirely, and reduce `TaskFileStorage` to just an `ObjectMapper` with the `JavaTimeModule` registered â€” no `SimpleModule` needed. The JSON output stays the same.
Want me to refactor to the annotation approach?
Now simplifying `TaskFileStorage` to just use `JavaTimeModule` instead of the custom `SimpleModule`.
Build successful â€” all 28 tests pass and checkstyle is clean.
- **`Task.java`** -- Added `@JsonTypeInfo` + `@JsonSubTypes` (maps `"type"` to the correct subclass) and `@JsonProperty` on `description` and `isDone` fields.
- **`Deadline.java`** -- Added `@JsonProperty("by")` on the field and `@JsonCreator` + `@JsonProperty` params on the constructor.
- **`Event.java`** -- Added `@JsonProperty("from")` / `@JsonProperty("to")` on the fields and `@JsonCreator` + `@JsonProperty` params on the constructor.
- **`TaskFileStorage.java`** -- Replaced the `SimpleModule` with custom serializer/deserializer with just `JavaTimeModule` + `WRITE_DATES_AS_TIMESTAMPS` disabled.
Jackson now handles everything through annotations and reflection, with no custom serialization logic required.
Error loading data: Could not resolve subtype of [simple type, class arnold.tasks.Task]: missing type id property 'type'
at [Source: REDACTED (`StreamReadFeature.INCLUDE_SOURCE_IN_LOCATION` disabled); line: 6, column: 1] (through reference chain: java.util.ArrayList[0])
com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.exc.InvalidTypeIdException: Could not resolve subtype of [simple type, class arnold.tasks.Task]: missing type id property 'type'
at [Source: REDACTED (`StreamReadFeature.INCLUDE_SOURCE_IN_LOCATION` disabled); line: 6, column: 1] (through reference chain: java.util.ArrayList[0])

The issue is that Jackson is auto-detecting getter methods, producing unwanted properties (`"taskType"` from `getTaskType()`, `"done"` from `isDone()`), and the `"type"` discriminator isn't being written. I need to disable getter auto-detection so Jackson only uses the explicitly annotated fields.

The problem is that Jackson auto-detects `getTaskType()` as property `"taskType"` and `isDone()` as property `"done"`, polluting the JSON. The `"type"` discriminator is likely being suppressed because of these conflicts. I'll add `@JsonAutoDetect` to disable getter auto-detection, so only explicitly `@JsonProperty`-annotated fields are serialized.
Build passes. Now delete the old `tasks.txt` data file if it exists so the app starts fresh with JSON, then test it end-to-end.

The fix was adding `@JsonAutoDetect` to `Task.java` to disable getter auto-detection. The root cause was that Jackson was auto-detecting `getTaskType()` as a `"taskType"` property and `isDone()` as a `"done"` property, which polluted the JSON output and interfered with the `@JsonTypeInfo` type discriminator. With getter auto-detection disabled, Jackson now only serializes explicitly `@JsonProperty`-annotated fields plus the `"type"` discriminator from `@JsonTypeInfo`. Give it another try -- the JSON should now look like:

The `"type"` discriminator is still missing. This is because `writeValueAsString()` infers the runtime type (`Todo`) directly, so Jackson skips the type info since it already "knows" the concrete type. The fix is to explicitly tell Jackson to serialize as `List<Task>` using `writerFor`.

Build passes. The issue was that `writeValueAsString(Object)` sees the runtime types directly and skips the type discriminator. Using `writerFor(new TypeReference<List<Task>>() {})` explicitly tells Jackson the declared type is `List<Task>`, which forces the `@JsonTypeInfo` to write the `"type"` field. Try it again â€” the JSON should now include the type:

By default, Jackson serializes `LocalDateTime` (and other Java 8 date/time types) as numeric arrays like `[2026, 2, 14, 10, 30, 0]` (year, month, day, hour, minute, second). Turning this off makes Jackson use ISO-8601 strings instead, e.g. `"2026-02-14T10:30:00"`, which are easier to read and work with.

Jacksonâ€™s core doesnâ€™t know how to serialize/deserialize `LocalDateTime`, `LocalDate`, `ZonedDateTime`, etc. The `JavaTimeModule` adds support for these types. Without it, Jackson would throw when it encounters a `LocalDateTime` (e.g. in `Deadline.by` or `Event.from`/`Event.to`).
This creates a writer configured to treat the value as `List<Task>` (the declared type), instead of using the runtime type of each element.

With `objectMapper.writeValueAsString(taskList.getTasks())`, Jackson infers types from the actual objects. For a list of `Todo`, it sees `List<Todo>` and serializes each item as a `Todo`. Because the concrete type is known, Jackson does not add the `@JsonTypeInfo` discriminator (`"type"`).

Using `writerFor(new TypeReference<List<Task>>() {})` tells Jackson the declared type is `List<Task>`. Each element is then treated as a polymorphic `Task`, so Jackson adds the `"type"` field (`"todo"`, `"deadline"`, `"event"`) to each object. That way, when loading, Jackson can choose the right subclass from the `"type"` field.

Because of type erasure, `List<Task>.class` is not valid and `List.class` loses the `Task` parameter. `TypeReference<List<Task>>() {}` is a common pattern that preserves the full generic type (`List<Task>`) so Jackson can use it for serialization.
why without this type = todo etc. is not registered?
**How Jackson decides whether to write the type discriminator**

`@JsonTypeInfo` tells Jackson to add a type discriminator when it treats the value as a **polymorphic** type â€” i.e. when the declared type is the base type (`Task`) and Jackson doesnâ€™t know the concrete subclass at compile time.
1. Jackson gets a `List` whose elements are `Todo`, `Deadline`, or `Event`.
2. It infers the type from the actual objects. For a list of `Todo`, it sees `List<Todo>`.
3. Because the element type is already `Todo`, Jackson treats it as a concrete type, not polymorphic.
4. Thereâ€™s no need for a discriminator: the type is known.
5. So `@JsonTypeInfo` is not used and `"type"` is not written.
1. Jackson is told the declared type is `List<Task>`.
2. For each element, the declared type is `Task` (the base class).
3. Jackson doesnâ€™t know the concrete subclass from the type alone; it must use polymorphism.
4. `@JsonTypeInfo` applies: Jackson writes the `"type"` field so it can reconstruct the right subclass when deserializing.
So the type discriminator is only written when Jackson treats the value as polymorphic. Without `writerFor`, it infers the concrete type and skips the discriminator.
- **`use = JsonTypeInfo.Id.NAME`** â€” Store the subtype as a string name (e.g. `"todo"`, `"deadline"`, `"event"`).
- **`property = "type"`** â€” Put that name in a JSON field called `"type"`.
So each serialized task gets a `"type"` field that tells Jackson which subclass to use when deserializing.
Defines the mapping from those type names to Java classes:
- **`value = Todo.class, name = "todo"`** â€” When `"type"` is `"todo"`, deserialize as `Todo`.
Without this, Jackson would not know how to turn `"todo"` into a `Todo` instance.
Controls which methods Jackson treats as properties:
- **`getterVisibility = NONE`** â€” Ignore getters like `getDescription()` and `getTaskType()`.
- **`isGetterVisibility = NONE`** â€” Ignore boolean getters like `isDone()`.
Jackson then only serializes fields that are explicitly annotated (e.g. with `@JsonProperty`). That avoids:
- `isDone()` being serialized as `"done"` (JavaBean naming for boolean getters).
So the JSON only contains the fields you want: `"type"`, `"description"`, `"isDone"`, and any subclass-specific fields.
# Identifying Git Commit Hashes for Tags
help me identify which commit hashes (usually merge commits) to add these tags
A-AiAssisted -m "Enhance the code using AI tools"
A-BetterGui -m "Improve the GUI" <- we can attach this to second latest commit
A-Personality -m "Give Arnold a unique personality" <- second latest commit
I'll analyze the git history to identify which commits correspond to each of these tags. Let me start by examining the repository structure and commit history.
[Runs multiple git commands in parallel to examine branches, commit history, and merge commits]
Based on my analysis of your git history, here are the commit hashes for each tag:
| Tag | Commit Hash | Description | Commit Message |
| **A-Assertions** | `8bc632a` | Merge PR #54 | "Merge pull request #54 from andrewsoonqn/branch-A-Assertions" |
| **A-CodeQuality** | `3733247` | Merge PR #58 | "Merge pull request #58 from andrewsoonqn/branch-A-CodeQuality" |
| **A-Streams** | `46351fb` | Merge PR #57 | "Merge pull request #57 from andrewsoonqn/branch-A-Streams" |
| **A-CI** | `687d1b6` | Merge PR #55 | "Merge pull request #55 from andrewsoonqn/branch-A-CI" |
| **C-NaturalDates** | `ad7fae9` | Merge PR #64 | "Merge pull request #64 from andrewsoonqn/branch-C-NaturalDates" |
| **BCD-Extension** | `ad7fae9` | Same as C-NaturalDates | Same merge commit |
| **A-AiAssisted** | `985df6a` | Merge PR #49 (AI docs) | "Merge pull request #49 from andrewsoonqn/ai-docs" |
| **A-MoreErrorHandling** | `7ae577f` | Merge PR #69 | "Merge pull request #69 from andrewsoonqn/load-save-error-visibility" |
| **A-MoreTesting** | `9524674` | Merge PR #72 | "Merge pull request #72 from andrewsoonqn/add-tests" |

**Note:** I couldn't find specific commits dedicated to "personality" or "Better GUI" as standalone features in the branch history. The commits you mentioned (2nd latest) appear to correspond to the testing merge.
1. Use different commits for A-BetterGui and A-Personality?
2. Check specific files for personality/GUI-related changes to identify better commits?
3. Create the tags on these commits as specified?
please create a list of commands, i want all. for gui and personality, i want head~
Here are the git tag commands based on your request:
# C-Level Extension (BCD-Extension points to same commit)
git tag -a C-NaturalDates ad7fae9 -m "Use more natural date formats"
git tag -a BCD-Extension ad7fae9 -m "Corresponding tag: C-NaturalDates"
git tag -a A-AiAssisted 985df6a -m "Enhance the code using AI tools"
git tag -a A-MoreErrorHandling 7ae577f -m "Handle all anticipated errors"
git tag -a A-MoreTesting 9524674 -m "Add more automated tests"
# GUI & Personality (both on second latest commit as requested)
git tag -a A-BetterGui HEAD~ -m "Improve the GUI"
git tag -a A-Personality HEAD~ -m "Give Arnold a unique personality"
**Note:** `HEAD~` points to commit `9524674` (Merge pull request #72 from andrewsoonqn/add-tests), which is the second latest commit on master.
**Potential Issue:** Both `A-MoreTesting` and `A-BetterGui`/`A-Personality` would be tagged on the same commit (9524674). Is this intentional, or would you prefer:
Please confirm if you want me to proceed with these commands, or if you'd like any adjustments!
let's do better gui and personality on HEAD
Perfect! Here's the updated command list with A-BetterGui and A-Personality on HEAD (the latest commit `57da6d2 "Move and rename Ui.png"`):
# C-Level Extension (BCD-Extension points to same commit)
git tag -a C-NaturalDates ad7fae9 -m "Use more natural date formats"
git tag -a BCD-Extension ad7fae9 -m "Corresponding tag: C-NaturalDates"
git tag -a A-AiAssisted 985df6a -m "Enhance the code using AI tools"
git tag -a A-MoreErrorHandling 7ae577f -m "Handle all anticipated errors"
git tag -a A-MoreTesting 9524674 -m "Add more automated tests"
git tag -a A-BetterGui HEAD -m "Improve the GUI"
git tag -a A-Personality HEAD -m "Give Arnold a unique personality"
- 10 lightweight tags (`-a` annotated tags with messages)
- All on merge commits except GUI/Personality on the latest commit
- BCD-Extension and C-NaturalDates share the same commit hash
Would you like me to execute these commands?
please help me improve the date section of my user guide. showcase the natural date handling
[Reads the existing `docs/README.md`, then reads both provided files]
Here's a summary of all changes made to `docs/README.md`:
**Removed** the old inline bullet-point date/time note under the `deadline` section (it was incomplete and slightly wrong â€” it didn't mention 4-digit times or the year-omission behaviour properly).
**Added** a new top-level `## Date & Time Format` section at the end with three sub-sections:

- **Date** â€” table of the three input forms (`day/month/year`, `day/month/yy`, `day/month`), a prose explanation of the smart future-resolution logic with a visual example, and the 2-digit year sliding-window table (00â€“49 â†’ 2000â€“2049, 50â€“99 â†’ 1950â€“1999).
- **Time** â€” table of all four digit-length forms (1â€“4 digits), the default-to-23:59 rule, and an explicit note that colons are rejected.
- **Quick reference** â€” a single consolidated table showing eight representative inputs and their resolved date/times (drawn directly from the test cases in `DateTimeParserTest.java`).
**Cross-references** were added in the `deadline` and `event` sections pointing to the new section, and their format lines were updated to show `[time]` as optional.

Arnold is a friendly task management chatbot that helps you keep track of your todos, deadlines, and events. With a simple command-line style interface and persistent storage, Arnold makes task management effortless.
2. Run the following command within the enclosing folder of the JAR file.
3. Type commands in the text field and press Enter or click Send.
4. Type `help` to see all available commands.

See [Date and Time Format](#date-and-time-format) for the full range of accepted inputs.

Search for tasks containing a specific keyword. The search is case-insensitive and matches any part of the task description.

A list of all available commands with descriptions and usage examples.
Exit Arnold and close the application after a short pause. Input fields and buttons will be disabled during this pause.
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
Arnold automatically saves your tasks to `./data/tasks.json` after every command. Your tasks will be restored when you restart the application, so you never lose track of what needs to be done.
Arnold accepts flexible date and time input. Both the year and the time are optional.
| `25/12/26` | Same but using 2-digit year, see below    |
| `25/12` | Year omitted: uses next future occurrence |
When the year is left out, Arnold automatically picks the next future occurrence of that day and month. If the date has already passed this year (or is today), next year is used instead.
25/12        â†’  25 Dec this year  (if that date is still in the future)
â†’  25 Dec next year  (if it has already passed)
Only 2-digit and 4-digit years are accepted; 1- or 3-digit years are invalid.
Colons are not accepted (`14:00` is invalid; use `1400`).

* A utility class for attaching example usage text to messages.
* This decouples example usage from the error messages themselves,
